title: Lemonade Change
patternTriggers: Cashier making change with limited bills? Track bill counts and greedily use larger bills first!

approaches.name: Greedy Bill Counting (Optimal)
approaches.intuition: Track count of $5 and $10 bills. For change, greedily use $10 first (prefer keeping $5 bills as they're more flexible).
approaches.approach: Maintain counts of $5 and $10 bills. For each customer, calculate required change and greedily provide it using available bills.

approaches.name: Greedy with Explicit Change Calculation
approaches.intuition: Same greedy strategy but with more explicit change calculation logic.
approaches.approach: Calculate change needed, then greedily use bills starting from largest denomination.
steps: Else: Try to make change greedily:
If can't make exact change: return false

commonMistakes: For $20 bill: using 3×$5 before trying 1×$10+1×$5 (wrong greedy choice - $5 bills are more valuable)
Not tracking $10 bills (only tracking $5) - need both counts
Trying to track all bills including $20 (unnecessary - $20 can't be used as change)
Not returning false immediately when can't make change
Not understanding why $5 bills are more flexible than $10 bills
hints: Lemonade costs $5, so we only receive $5, $10, or $20 bills
We can't give $20 as change (larger than any change needed)
For $20 bill: prefer giving 1×$10+1×$5 over 3×$5 (saves flexible $5 bills)
Why $5 more valuable? Can be used for any change, $10 can only help with $15 or $20 change
Greedy works: make best local decision (prefer $10+$5) leads to global optimum
Only need to track $5 and $10 counts, not individual bills
followUp: What if lemonade costs $3? (Different denominations, same greedy approach)
